The **Jacksonville Jaguars** are an [American](/wiki/United_States "United
States") [professional football](/wiki/Professional_football_\(gridiron\)
"Professional football \(gridiron\)") franchise based in [Jacksonville,
Florida](/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida "Jacksonville, Florida"). The Jaguars
compete in the [National Football League](/wiki/National_Football_League
"National Football League") (NFL) as a member club of the [American Football
Conference](/wiki/American_Football_Conference "American Football Conference")
(AFC) [South](/wiki/AFC_South "AFC South") division. The team plays its home
games at [TIAA Bank Field](/wiki/TIAA_Bank_Field "TIAA Bank Field").

The Jaguars and the [Carolina Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina
Panthers") joined the NFL as [expansion teams](/wiki/Expansion_team "Expansion
team") for the [1995 season](/wiki/1995_NFL_season "1995 NFL season"). Since
their inception, the Jaguars have won division championships in
[1998](/wiki/1998_NFL_season "1998 NFL season") and
[1999](/wiki/1999_NFL_season "1999 NFL season") (as members of the now-defunct
AFC Central) and [2017](/wiki/2017_NFL_season "2017 NFL season") (as members
of the [AFC South](/wiki/AFC_South "AFC South")) and have qualified for the
[playoffs](/wiki/NFL_playoffs "NFL playoffs") seven times, most recently in
[2017](/wiki/2017_NFL_season "2017 NFL season") after a ten-season playoff
drought.[4]

From their inception until [2011](/wiki/2011_NFL_season "2011 NFL season"),
the Jacksonville Jaguars' majority owner was [Wayne Weaver](/wiki/Wayne_Weaver
"Wayne Weaver"). The team was then purchased by [Pakistani](/wiki/Pakistan
"Pakistan")-born businessman [Shahid Khan](/wiki/Shahid_Khan "Shahid Khan")
for an estimated [$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")770
million.[5][6] In 2015, [Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes") estimated the team
value at $1.48 billion.[7]

## Franchise
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Franchise history")]

Main article: [History of the Jacksonville
Jaguars](/wiki/History_of_the_Jacksonville_Jaguars "History of the
Jacksonville Jaguars")

###
1989–1994[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: 1989–1994")]

[![A david
garrard.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/US_Navy_041227-N-6631E-001_Commanding_officer_of_the_aircraft_carrier_USS_John_F._Kennedy_%28CV_67%29%2C_Capt._Dennis_E._FitzPatrick_shakes_hands_with_Jacksonville_Jaguar_owner_Wayne_Weaver.jpg/215px-
thumbnail.jpg)](/wiki/File:US_Navy_041227-N-6631E-001_Commanding_officer_of_the_aircraft_carrier_USS_John_F._Kennedy_\(CV_67\),_Capt._Dennis_E._FitzPatrick_shakes_hands_with_Jacksonville_Jaguar_owner_Wayne_Weaver.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:US_Navy_041227-N-6631E-001_Commanding_officer_of_the_aircraft_carrier_USS_John_F._Kennedy_\(CV_67\),_Capt._Dennis_E._FitzPatrick_shakes_hands_with_Jacksonville_Jaguar_owner_Wayne_Weaver.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Wayne Weaver](/wiki/Wayne_Weaver "Wayne Weaver") (right) was the first owner
of the Jacksonville Jaguars from 1993 to 2011.

In 1989, the prospective ownership group _Touchdown Jacksonville!_ was
organized. The group initially included future Florida Governor [Jeb
Bush](/wiki/Jeb_Bush "Jeb Bush") and Jacksonville developer [Tom
Petway](/wiki/Tom_Petway "Tom Petway"), and came to be led by shoe magnate
[Wayne Weaver](/wiki/Wayne_Weaver "Wayne Weaver"), founder of [Nine
West](/wiki/Nine_West "Nine West"). In 1991, the NFL announced plans to add
two expansion teams in 1994 (later delayed until 1995), its first expansion
since the 1976 addition of the [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks
"Seattle Seahawks") and the [Tampa Bay Buccaneers](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers
"Tampa Bay Buccaneers"). Touchdown Jacksonville! announced its bid for a team,
and Jacksonville was ultimately chosen as one of five finalists, along with
[Charlotte](/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina "Charlotte, North Carolina"), [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri "St. Louis, Missouri"),
[Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore,_Maryland "Baltimore, Maryland"), and
[Memphis](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee").[8]

Jacksonville was considered the least likely expansion candidate for several
reasons. The [Jacksonville metropolitan
area](/wiki/Jacksonville_metropolitan_area "Jacksonville metropolitan area")
and television market were smaller than those of nearly every team in the
league.[8] Although Jacksonville was the 15th largest city in the nation at
the time (It has since grown to become the 11th-largest), it has always been a
medium-sized market because the surrounding suburbs and rural areas are far
smaller than the city itself. There were 635,000 people in Jacksonville proper
according to the 1990 census, but only 900,000 people in the metropolitan
area.[9][10] Additionally, the Gator Bowl was outdated, and the ownership
group struggled to negotiate a lease with the city. The troubled negotiations
over the Gator Bowl lease led the ownership group to withdraw from the NFL
expansion bidding in July 1993.[8]

Charlotte was awarded the first franchise – the [Carolina
Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers") – in October 1993.
Surprisingly, the naming of the second expansion city was delayed a month.
Most pundits speculated that the delay was made to allow St. Louis to shore up
its bid. At the time, St. Louis was considered the favorite for the second
franchise, with Baltimore's three bids also considered strong. However, in a
surprising move, the NFL owners voted 26–2 in favor of awarding the 30th
franchise to Jacksonville.[8]

After the Gator Bowl game on December 31, 1993, the old stadium was
essentially demolished and replaced with a reinforced concrete superstructure.
All that remained of the old stadium was the west upper concourse and a
portion of the ramping system.[11] To accommodate construction, the 1994 and
1995 games of "The World's Largest Outdoor Cocktail Party" were split between
the home fields of Florida and Georgia, and the [1994 Gator
Bowl](/wiki/1994_Gator_Bowl "1994 Gator Bowl") was played at [Ben Hill Griffin
Stadium](/wiki/Ben_Hill_Griffin_Stadium "Ben Hill Griffin Stadium") in
[Gainesville](/wiki/Gainesville,_Florida "Gainesville, Florida").[12]

###
1995–2002[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1995–2002")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Army.Coughlin.jpg/220px-
Army.Coughlin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Army.Coughlin.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Army.Coughlin.jpg "Enlarge")

[Tom Coughlin](/wiki/Tom_Coughlin "Tom Coughlin") was Jacksonville's head
coach for its first eight seasons

In January 1994 [Wayne Weaver](/wiki/Wayne_Weaver "Wayne Weaver") chose [Tom
Coughlin](/wiki/Tom_Coughlin "Tom Coughlin") as the first-ever head coach of
the Jaguars. Coughlin had worked in the NFL as a position coach, but he had
been neither a head coach nor a coordinator in the NFL.[13]

The Jaguars' hiring of Coughlin contrasted with the hiring moves made by their
fellow expansion team. The same month that Weaver hired Coughlin as his head
_coach_ , [Carolina Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers")
owner [Jerry Richardson](/wiki/Jerry_Richardson "Jerry Richardson") went a
more conventional route and hired former [Buffalo Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills
"Buffalo Bills") general manager [Bill Polian](/wiki/Bill_Polian "Bill
Polian") as the Panthers' first GM (the Panthers' head coach, [Dom
Capers](/wiki/Dom_Capers "Dom Capers"), would not be hired until a full year
after Coughlin). As it emerged that Weaver had no intention of hiring a
general manager, it became apparent that Coughlin would have most of the
authority regarding hiring decisions. Coughlin spent his year as "head coach
without a team"[13] preparing for the personnel moves that would come from the
expansion draft, free agency, and the rookie draft in the spring of 1995.

#### 1995[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 1995")]

Main article: [1995 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/1995_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "1995 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

[![A david
garrard.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b6/JaguarsInauguralSeasonlogo.gif/215px-
JaguarsInauguralSeasonlogo.gif)](/wiki/File:JaguarsInauguralSeasonlogo.gif)

[](/wiki/File:JaguarsInauguralSeasonlogo.gif "Enlarge")

The inaugural logo of the Jacksonville Jaguars.

Along with the [Carolina Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina
Panthers"), the Jacksonville Jaguars entered the [NFL](/wiki/NFL "NFL") as the
first expansion teams in almost 20 years. Both teams participated in the [1995
NFL expansion draft](/wiki/1995_NFL_expansion_draft "1995 NFL expansion
draft"), with the Jaguars taking [Steve Beuerlein](/wiki/Steve_Beuerlein
"Steve Beuerlein") with the first pick. Beuerlein quickly lost his starting
job to former Green Bay Packers backup [Mark Brunell](/wiki/Mark_Brunell "Mark
Brunell"). The Jaguars finished their inaugural season with a record of 4–12.
Both the Jaguars and the Panthers (7–9) broke the previous record for most
wins by an expansion team (3) set by the [Cincinnati
Bengals](/wiki/Cincinnati_Bengals "Cincinnati Bengals") in 1968.[14] The
inaugural season featured many of the players who would lead Jacksonville into
the playoffs in the team's next four seasons, including quarterback [Mark
Brunell](/wiki/Mark_Brunell "Mark Brunell") (acquired in a draft day trade
from Green Bay), offensive lineman [Tony Boselli](/wiki/Tony_Boselli "Tony
Boselli") (drafted with the 2nd pick overall in the [1995 NFL
Draft](/wiki/1995_NFL_Draft "1995 NFL Draft")) running back [James
Stewart](/wiki/James_Stewart_\(football_player\) "James Stewart \(football
player\)") (also drafted in 1995), and wide receiver [Jimmy
Smith](/wiki/Jimmy_Smith_\(wide_receiver\) "Jimmy Smith \(wide receiver\)")
(signed as a free agent).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/MarkBrunell95.jpg/220px-
MarkBrunell95.jpg)](/wiki/File:MarkBrunell95.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MarkBrunell95.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mark Brunell](/wiki/Mark_Brunell "Mark Brunell") practicing with the Jaguars
before their inaugural game on September 3, 1995.

The team played its first regular season game at home in front of a crowd of
72,363[15] on September 3, 1995, a 10–3 loss against the [Houston
Oilers](/wiki/Houston_Oilers "Houston Oilers"). The team picked up its first
win in Week 4 as the Jaguars defeated the Oilers 17–16 on October 1 in
Houston. The next week against the Pittsburgh Steelers, the Jaguars earned
their first home win by defeating the eventual AFC Champions 20–16. The team's
other two wins came in a season sweep of the [Cleveland
Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") including a Week 17 24–21
victory sealed by a Mike Hollis 34-yard field goal[16] in the Browns' final
game before the team relocated to Baltimore and was renamed the Ravens.

#### 1996[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 1996")]

Main article: [1996 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/1996_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "1996 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

Jacksonville's 1996 season was a marked success as they won six of their last
seven games of the season and finished with a record of 9–7. Quarterback [Mark
Brunell](/wiki/Mark_Brunell "Mark Brunell") threw for over 4,000 yards and
wide receivers [Keenan McCardell](/wiki/Keenan_McCardell "Keenan McCardell")
and [Jimmy Smith](/wiki/Jimmy_Smith_\(wide_receiver\) "Jimmy Smith \(wide
receiver\)") each accumulated over 1,000 receiving yards. In the team's final
game of the regular season against the [Atlanta Falcons](/wiki/Atlanta_Falcons
"Atlanta Falcons"), needing a win to earn a playoff berth, the Jaguars caught
a bit of luck when [Morten Andersen](/wiki/Morten_Andersen "Morten Andersen"),
one of the most accomplished kickers in NFL history, missed a 30-yard field
goal with less than a minute remaining that would have given the Falcons the
lead.[17] The Jaguars clinched the fifth seed in the AFC playoffs.

The Jaguars visited the [Buffalo Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills "Buffalo Bills")
in their first playoff game in franchise history. Despite being a heavy
underdog, the Jaguars won 30–27, and knocked Buffalo quarterback [Jim
Kelly](/wiki/Jim_Kelly "Jim Kelly") out of what would turn out to be the last
game of his career. Their next game was on the road against the [Denver
Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos"), who had earned the AFC's top
seed with a 13–3 record and were widely regarded as the best team in the AFC,
if not the NFL. While the Broncos scored two touchdowns early in the game,
after the first quarter, the Jaguars largely dominated. In what is often
regarded as one of the three biggest upsets in NFL playoff
history,[18][19][20] the Jaguars defeated the Broncos by the same score as the
previous week against the Bills, 30–27. Upon their return home, the Jags were
greeted by an estimated 40,000 fans at the stadium. Many of these fans had
watched the game on the stadium [JumboTron](/wiki/JumboTron "JumboTron")
displays and had stayed into the early hours of the morning when the team
arrived. In the AFC Championship Game, the Jaguars miracle season came to an
end, as they lost 20–6 to the [New England
Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots"), in Foxboro.
Their fellow second-year NFC expansion team, the Carolina Panthers, also got
to their conference championship game, where they lost 30–13 to the eventual
Super Bowl champion [Green Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay
Packers").[21]

####
1997–99[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 1997–99")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/JaguarsBengalsJan2000.jpg/320px-
JaguarsBengalsJan2000.jpg)](/wiki/File:JaguarsBengalsJan2000.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:JaguarsBengalsJan2000.jpg "Enlarge")

Jacksonville Jaguars vs. Cincinnati Bengals in January 2000.

Main article: [1997 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/1997_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "1997 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

In **1997** , the franchise's third season, the Jaguars and the Steelers both
finished the season with an 11–5 record, tops in the AFC Central Division.
Pittsburgh won the division in a tiebreaker as a result of having higher net
in division games than Jacksonville.[22] As a result, the Jaguars settled for
2nd place in the division, a Wild Card berth and, for the second straight
year, the 5th seed in the AFC playoffs. The Jags postseason would end quickly
as they fell in their first game, a 42–17 defeat against the eventual [Super
Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl_32 "Super Bowl 32") champion [Denver
Broncos](/wiki/1997_Denver_Broncos_season "1997 Denver Broncos season") at
[Mile High Stadium](/wiki/Mile_High_Stadium "Mile High Stadium"). The Broncos,
led by [Terrell Davis](/wiki/Terrell_Davis "Terrell Davis"), ran at will
against the Jaguars, rushing for 5 touchdowns and over 300 yards.[23]

Main article: [1998 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/1998_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "1998 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

In **1998** , the Jaguars again finished 11–5 and won their first AFC Central
Division title. The team became the first NFL expansion team to make the
playoffs three times in its first four seasons of play. In the Wild Card
Round, the Jaguars hosted their first home playoff game, a 25–10 win over the
New England Patriots. The team's season ended the next week in the Divisional
Round as the [New York Jets](/wiki/New_York_Jets "New York Jets") defeated the
Jaguars 34–24.[24]

Main article: [1999 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/1999_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "1999 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

In **1999** , the Jaguars compiled a league best 14–2 regular season record,
the best record in franchise history. The team's two losses were to the
[Tennessee Titans](/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans"). The Jaguars won
the AFC Central Division for the second straight year and clinched the #1 seed
in the AFC. The Jaguars hosted the Miami Dolphins in the AFC Divisional
playoffs, a 62–7 victory in what would be [Dan Marino](/wiki/Dan_Marino "Dan
Marino") and [Jimmy Johnson](/wiki/Jimmy_Johnson_\(American_football_coach\)
"Jimmy Johnson \(American football coach\)")'s last NFL game. Jacksonville's
62 points and 55-point margin are the second most ever in NFL playoff history,
and [Fred Taylor](/wiki/Fred_Taylor_\(American_football\) "Fred Taylor
\(American football\)")'s 90-yard run in the first quarter is the longest ever
in an NFL playoff game.[25]

The Jaguars' bid for a Super Bowl title came to an end the next week in the
AFC championship game. The Jags fell at home to the Titans 33–14 in a game
that the Jaguars led 14–10 at halftime, before allowing 23 unanswered points
in the 2nd half. The Jaguars finished the 1999 season 15–3, with all three of
their losses coming against the Titans. The loss marked the end of an era that
saw the Jaguars make the playoffs in four of the team's first 5 years and
would be the team's last playoff appearance until the 2005 season.[26]

####
2000–02[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 2000–02")]

Main articles: [2000 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2000_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2000 Jacksonville Jaguars
season"), [2001 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2001_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2001 Jacksonville Jaguars
season"), and [2002 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2002_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2002 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

The Jaguars struggled during this period, due in part to salary cap
problems.[27] In the 2000 season, veteran quarterback Mark Brunell and young
running back Fred Taylor led the squad through a painful 7–9 season. The
Jaguars finished with records of 6–10 in both the 2001 and 2002 seasons.

After the 2002 season, head coach [Tom Coughlin](/wiki/Tom_Coughlin "Tom
Coughlin") was fired after eight seasons, leading the Jaguars to a total
record of 68–60 and four trips to the playoffs. The 2002 season also marked
the last full season for Jaguars quarterback [Mark Brunell](/wiki/Mark_Brunell
"Mark Brunell"), who was benched in the third game of 2003 in favor of [Byron
Leftwich](/wiki/Byron_Leftwich "Byron Leftwich"). Brunell piled up over 25,000
yards as a Jaguar and earned three trips to the [Pro Bowl](/wiki/Pro_Bowl "Pro
Bowl"). In 2002 the NFL split up the two conferences into four divisions,
sending the Jacksonville Jaguars to the AFC South. This put them in the same
division as the [Indianapolis Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis
Colts"), Tennessee Titans, and the expansion [Houston
Texans](/wiki/Houston_Texans "Houston Texans").[28]

###
2003–2011[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 2003–2011")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Jack_del_Rio_2008.jpg/125px-
Jack_del_Rio_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jack_del_Rio_2008.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jack_del_Rio_2008.jpg "Enlarge")

Head Coach [Jack Del Rio](/wiki/Jack_Del_Rio "Jack Del Rio") set an NFL-record
for consecutive seasons (9) coaching a team without once winning a division
title.

####
2003–05[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: 2003–05")]

Main articles: [2003 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2003_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2003 Jacksonville Jaguars
season"), [2004 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2004_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2004 Jacksonville Jaguars
season"), and [2005 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2005_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2005 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

In 2003, the Jaguars hired [Jack Del Rio](/wiki/Jack_Del_Rio "Jack Del Rio")
as head coach. Del Rio was a linebacker during the late 80s and early 90s
before retiring. He was formerly the Carolina Panthers' defensive coordinator,
bringing the team's defensive ranking from 30th to second. Prior to that, Del
Rio was the [Baltimore Ravens](/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens "Baltimore Ravens")
linebackers coach, participating in that capacity on the Ravens' record
setting championship 2000 defense. The Jaguars selected quarterback [Byron
Leftwich](/wiki/Byron_Leftwich "Byron Leftwich") with the seventh pick of the
NFL draft. The Jaguars had high hopes for their new quarterback. The team had
many failures and heartbreaking moments, ending the 2003 season at 5–11 and
missing the playoffs for the fourth consecutive season. Despite resolving
their salary cap problems, the team's rebuilding was clearly taking longer
than expected.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Byron_Leftwich_Jaguars_2005.jpg/300px-
Byron_Leftwich_Jaguars_2005.jpg)](/wiki/File:Byron_Leftwich_Jaguars_2005.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Byron_Leftwich_Jaguars_2005.jpg "Enlarge")

[Josh Scobee](/wiki/Josh_Scobee "Josh Scobee") is the all-time leading scorer
for the Jaguars with 1,022 points.

The 2004 season, the 10th season of the Jaguars franchise, resulted in a 9–7
record, their first winning season since 1999, with road victories against the
Green Bay Packers at [Lambeau Field](/wiki/Lambeau_Field "Lambeau Field") and
the [Indianapolis Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis Colts") at the
[RCA Dome](/wiki/RCA_Dome "RCA Dome"). The Jaguars' defense was a strong suit,
as it included two Pro Bowl players, defensive tackles [Marcus
Stroud](/wiki/Marcus_Stroud "Marcus Stroud") and [John
Henderson](/wiki/John_Henderson_\(NFL_football\) "John Henderson \(NFL
football\)"). [Josh Scobee](/wiki/Josh_Scobee "Josh Scobee") was selected in
the 5th round of the [2004 NFL Draft](/wiki/2004_NFL_Draft "2004 NFL Draft")
and became a dominant [placekicker](/wiki/Placekicker "Placekicker") for the
Jaguars setting multiple franchise records.[29] Byron Leftwich enjoyed a solid
year in 2004, helped by strong performances from holdovers [Fred
Taylor](/wiki/Fred_Taylor_\(American_football\) "Fred Taylor \(American
football\)") and [Jimmy Smith](/wiki/Jimmy_Smith_\(wide_receiver\) "Jimmy
Smith \(wide receiver\)"). Unfortunately, Taylor sustained a season-ending
injury at Green Bay. The very next week the Jaguars fell to the Houston
Texans, which would ultimately eliminate them from playoff contention.[30]

The 2005 Jaguars hoped to challenge the Colts for the division title. However,
due to their scintillating 13–0 start, including two victories against the
Jaguars, the Colts easily clinched the AFC South title. With a 12–4 record,
the Jaguars earned a wild card and their first playoff appearance since 1999.
While the Jaguars managed to win key games in 2005, nine of their final ten
games were against opponents with losing records. Though these games were
wins, key players Byron Leftwich, [Mike Peterson](/wiki/Mike_Peterson "Mike
Peterson"), [Akin Ayodele](/wiki/Akin_Ayodele "Akin Ayodele"), [Paul
Spicer](/wiki/Paul_Spicer "Paul Spicer"), and [Rashean
Mathis](/wiki/Rashean_Mathis "Rashean Mathis") were hurt during this stretch.
The Jaguars ended the season losing 28–3 to the two-time defending champion
[New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") on
January 7, 2006 in the AFC wild card playoff round.[31]

####
2006[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: 2006")]

Main article: [2006 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2006_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2006 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

Jacksonville looked like a team on the rise coming off of their 12–4 season,
and was considered a playoff contender entering the season. But injuries
plagued the team. [Reggie Hayward](/wiki/Reggie_Hayward "Reggie Hayward"),
[Greg Jones](/wiki/Greg_Jones_\(American_football\) "Greg Jones \(American
football\)"), [Donovin Darius](/wiki/Donovin_Darius "Donovin Darius"), Byron
Leftwich, and Mike Peterson all suffered season-ending injuries. Marcus
Stroud, [Matt Jones](/wiki/Matt_Jones_\(American_football\) "Matt Jones
\(American football\)"), Paul Spicer, and Fred Taylor also faced injuries
during the season. The team started off 2–0, defeating the [Dallas
Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys") (earning the NFL's highest
winning percentage on opening days at .750 with a record of 9–3), and shutting
out the defending champs Pittsburgh Steelers. But the team lost its next two
games, and suffered embarrassing losses to the [Houston
Texans](/wiki/Houston_Texans "Houston Texans") over the course of the season
(Jacksonville has struggled against the Texans since Houston entered the
league in 2002). They missed the playoffs with an 8–8 record, but there were
some positives, in particular an impressive rookie season by their second-
round draft pick, running back [Maurice Jones-Drew](/wiki/Maurice_Jones-Drew
"Maurice Jones-Drew").[32]

####
2007[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: 2007")]

Main article: [2007 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2007_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2007 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

In the [2007 NFL Draft](/wiki/2007_NFL_Draft "2007 NFL Draft"), the Jaguars
used their first-round pick (21st overall) to select Florida safety [Reggie
Nelson](/wiki/Reggie_Nelson "Reggie Nelson"). On June 15, 2007, the Jaguars
released veteran strong safety [Donovin Darius](/wiki/Donovin_Darius "Donovin
Darius"), who had seen diminished playing time in previous years due to
mounting injuries. On August 31, 2007, the Jaguars announced that long time
back-up quarterback [David Garrard](/wiki/David_Garrard "David Garrard") would
start for the team, ahead of former first round draft pick [Byron
Leftwich](/wiki/Byron_Leftwich "Byron Leftwich"), who was released in the
team's final roster cuts. Garrard led the Jaguars to an 11–5 record and a wild
card spot in the [playoffs](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_NFL_playoffs "2007–08 NFL
playoffs"). The Jaguars defeated the [Pittsburgh
Steelers](/wiki/2007_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2007 Pittsburgh Steelers
season") 31–29 to win their first playoff game in almost eight years and their
first road playoff win since 1997. It was also the first time in the 50+ year
history of the Steelers that they had been beaten twice at home by the same
team in the same season. However, in the divisional round, the Jaguars fell to
the then-undefeated [New England
Patriots](/wiki/2007_New_England_Patriots_season "2007 New England Patriots
season"); the teams were tied at halftime, but the Patriots pulled ahead and
won 31–20. [Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom Brady") completed 26 of 28 passes
in this game, being pressured by the Jaguars' defense only once, on the first
play. This game, more than any other, gave the Jaguars' front office a strong
desire to upgrade the pass rush during the offseason.

The team's offense in 2007 was largely a run-first offense, with [Maurice
Jones-Drew](/wiki/Maurice_Jones-Drew "Maurice Jones-Drew") and [Fred
Taylor](/wiki/Fred_Taylor_\(American_football\) "Fred Taylor \(American
football\)") each putting up a lot of yards. David Garrard, however showed to
be an efficient passer in 2007, throwing only 3 interceptions.

####
2008[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: 2008")]

Main article: [2008 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2008_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2008 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

The 2008 season began with high expectations for the Jaguars. The team
acquired free agent wide receiver [Jerry
Porter](/wiki/Jerry_Porter_\(American_football\) "Jerry Porter \(American
football\)") and rookie defensive ends [Quentin Groves](/wiki/Quentin_Groves
"Quentin Groves") of Auburn and [Derrick Harvey](/wiki/Derrick_Harvey "Derrick
Harvey") of Florida to address the team's most glaring needs. (Porter was
released the following year and Groves was traded to Oakland in 2010.)
Journalists including ESPN.com's Kevin Seifert predicted the Jaguars were
poised to make a Super Bowl run.[33]

However, the Jaguars failed to live up to those expectations, struggling to a
5–11 finish, the franchise's worst record since 2003. The team's struggles
were in part, the result of a rash of injuries to the team's offensive line.
The Jaguars lost starting guards [Vince Manuwai](/wiki/Vince_Manuwai "Vince
Manuwai") and [Maurice Williams](/wiki/Maurice_Williams_\(offensive_tackle\)
"Maurice Williams \(offensive tackle\)") for the season within the first
quarter of the opening game. Tackle [Richard Collier](/wiki/Richard_Collier
"Richard Collier")'s career ended in early September when he was brutally
attacked and shot 14 times.[34] Center Brad Meester missed the first two
months of the season and guard Chris Naeole, signed to the roster mid-season
in response to these injuries, was injured in pregame warmups before playing a
single snap. The 2008 season marked the end of running back [Fred
Taylor](/wiki/Fred_Taylor_\(American_football\) "Fred Taylor \(American
football\)")'s 11-year career as a Jaguar. Taylor, who is considered to be one
of the greatest Jaguars in the history of the franchise, rushed for over
10,000 yards during his tenure with Jacksonville and earned one trip to the
[Pro Bowl](/wiki/Pro_Bowl "Pro Bowl"). In 2009, he signed with the [New
England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots"). Taylor's
departure opened up the door for [Maurice Jones-Drew](/wiki/Maurice_Jones-Drew
"Maurice Jones-Drew") to become the team's feature running back. In 2011,
Taylor signed a one-day contract so he could retire as a Jaguar.[35]

####
2009–2010[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: 2009–2010")]

Main articles: [2009 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2009_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2009 Jacksonville Jaguars
season") and [2010 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2010_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2010 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

The Jaguars hoped to begin a new era in 2009 under their first-ever general
manager, [Gene Smith](/wiki/Gene_Smith_\(American_football_executive\) "Gene
Smith \(American football executive\)"). Smith made his mark early on in the
[2009 NFL Draft](/wiki/2009_NFL_Draft "2009 NFL Draft") by acquiring talent
such as [Eugene Monroe](/wiki/Eugene_Monroe "Eugene Monroe"), [Terrance
Knighton](/wiki/Terrance_Knighton "Terrance Knighton"), [Derek
Cox](/wiki/Derek_Cox "Derek Cox"), [Eben Britton](/wiki/Eben_Britton "Eben
Britton") and [Mike Thomas](/wiki/Mike_Thomas_\(wide_receiver,_born_1987\)
"Mike Thomas \(wide receiver, born 1987\)"), who all made significant
contributions in their rookie years. The Jaguars finished off this season 7–9
and did not manage to make the playoffs. In the offseason, the Jaguars parted
ways with veteran players [John
Henderson](/wiki/John_Henderson_\(defensive_tackle\) "John Henderson
\(defensive tackle\)") and [Reggie Hayward](/wiki/Reggie_Hayward "Reggie
Hayward") as part of the team's "youth movement".

[![A david
garrard.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Jaguars2009Entrance.jpg/275px-
Jaguars2009Entrance.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jaguars2009Entrance.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jaguars2009Entrance.jpg "Enlarge")

The Jaguars entrance in 2009.

However, 2009 also saw the team's attendance numbers plummet, leading to
television [blackouts](/wiki/Blackout_\(broadcasting\) "Blackout
\(broadcasting\)") and speculation that the team could eventually be moved or
sold.[36] 2009 marked a low point, with the team's attendance averaging around
50,000,[37] causing seven of the eight home games to be blacked out, and
leading NFL commissioner [Roger Goodell](/wiki/Roger_Goodell "Roger Goodell")
to address the issue with owner Wayne Weaver.[36][38] Jacksonville is one of
the league's smallest markets, though its stadium is relatively large; since
2005 the team has covered nearly 10,000 of the stadium's 73,000 total seats
with tarp in order to lower the stadium's official capacity to a more typical
size and reduce blackouts.[39] 73,000 total seats still ranks as one of the
largest in the NFL. From 2008 the team further suffered from the [late-2000s
recession](/wiki/Late-2000s_recession "Late-2000s recession"), which hit
Florida particularly hard, and structural changes within the NFL that
disadvantage teams in smaller markets.[36]

In 2010, to address this issue, the team and the City of Jacksonville
undertook several measures aimed at ensuring the franchise's continued
viability in Jacksonville. Supporters began the "Team Teal" drive to drum up
ticket sales.[40][41] The city negotiated a five-year, $16.6 million naming
rights deal with Jacksonville-based [EverBank](/wiki/EverBank "EverBank") to
rename the stadium [EverBank Field](/wiki/EverBank_Field "EverBank
Field").[36][42] As a result, the Jaguars' attendance increased dramatically
in 2010. While attendance figures were stagnant for most of the NFL,
Jacksonville saw an increase of 36.5%, by far the highest in the league, and
had none of their home games blacked out.[43][44]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/NightJXFL112.jpg/220px-
NightJXFL112.jpg)](/wiki/File:NightJXFL112.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NightJXFL112.jpg "Enlarge")

[Wells Fargo Center](/wiki/Wells_Fargo_Center_\(Jacksonville\) "Wells Fargo
Center \(Jacksonville\)") with their "Go Jaguars" lighting for the [2011
Jacksonville Jaguars season](/wiki/2011_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2011
Jacksonville Jaguars season")

The 2010 season proved a big year for the Jaguars on the field as well.
Running back [Maurice Jones-Drew](/wiki/Maurice_Jones-Drew "Maurice Jones-
Drew") emerged as second in the league in rushing yards and [David
Garrard](/wiki/David_Garrard "David Garrard") threw for 23 touchdowns, a
franchise record. [Marcedes Lewis](/wiki/Marcedes_Lewis "Marcedes Lewis") went
to his first pro bowl and the Jags had one of the best young defensive tackle
duo with [Terrance Knighton](/wiki/Terrance_Knighton "Terrance Knighton") and
rookie [Tyson Alualu](/wiki/Tyson_Alualu "Tyson Alualu").[45] [Josh
Scobee](/wiki/Josh_Scobee "Josh Scobee") set a team record with a 59-yard
field goal to beat the [Indianapolis Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts
"Indianapolis Colts"). Heading into December, Jacksonville was at the top of
the AFC South and in playoff contention. In Week 15, they lost to
Indianapolis, 34–24, which placed the Colts back atop the AFC South. The
Jaguars lost their last two games, placing themselves out of playoff
contention. They finished the season 8–8.

####
2011[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: 2011")]

Main article: [2011 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2011_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2011 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

[![A 9/11
anniversary.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/US_Navy_110911-N-YR391-035_Service_members%2C_firemen_and_police_officers_participate_in_a_ceremony_commemorating_the_10th_anniversary_of_the_Sept._1.jpg/220px-
US_Navy_110911-N-YR391-035_Service_members%2C_firemen_and_police_officers_participate_in_a_ceremony_commemorating_the_10th_anniversary_of_the_Sept._1.jpg)](/wiki/File:US_Navy_110911-N-YR391-035_Service_members,_firemen_and_police_officers_participate_in_a_ceremony_commemorating_the_10th_anniversary_of_the_Sept._1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:US_Navy_110911-N-YR391-035_Service_members,_firemen_and_police_officers_participate_in_a_ceremony_commemorating_the_10th_anniversary_of_the_Sept._1.jpg
"Enlarge")

The 2011 season began on the 10th anniversary of the [9/11
attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks").

In the [2011 NFL draft](/wiki/2011_NFL_draft "2011 NFL draft"), the Jaguars
traded a first and a second round pick in order to move up to the 10th pick
and select Missouri quarterback [Blaine Gabbert](/wiki/Blaine_Gabbert "Blaine
Gabbert").[46]

On September 6, 2011, quarterback David Garrard was cut from the team just
days before the start of the season; [Luke McCown](/wiki/Luke_McCown "Luke
McCown") was named starter. The move was similar to the one that named Garrard
himself the starter over Byron Leftwich in 2007. McCown started two games
until he threw four interceptions in a lopsided loss to the [New York
Jets](/wiki/2011_New_York_Jets_season "2011 New York Jets season") and Blaine
Gabbert was named the starter the following week. The Jaguars offense would
continue to struggle under the rookie quarterback, losing the next 4 games in
a row, until an upset victory over the [Baltimore
Ravens](/wiki/2011_Baltimore_Ravens_season "2011 Baltimore Ravens season") at
home on [Monday Night Football](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night
Football").

On November 29, 2011, owner [Wayne Weaver](/wiki/Wayne_Weaver "Wayne Weaver")
announced the firing of head coach [Jack Del Rio](/wiki/Jack_Del_Rio "Jack Del
Rio"), whose record had been 3–8 through the first 12 weeks of the season and
68–71 over his 9-year tenure. Del Rio was succeeded by defensive coordinator
[Mel Tucker](/wiki/Mel_Tucker "Mel Tucker") on an interim basis. Weaver also
announced that General Manager [Gene
Smith](/wiki/Gene_Smith_\(American_football_executive\) "Gene Smith \(American
football executive\)") had been given a three-year extension of his contract.

### 2012[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: 2012")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Shahid_Khan_2012.jpg/150px-
Shahid_Khan_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shahid_Khan_2012.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Shahid_Khan_2012.jpg "Enlarge")

Businessman [Shahid Khan](/wiki/Shahid_Khan "Shahid Khan") purchased the
Jaguars in 2012.

Immediately following the announcement of Del Rio being fired, Weaver also
announced that the team would be sold to Illinois businessman [Shahid
Khan](/wiki/Shahid_Khan "Shahid Khan").[47][48] Khan's assumption of ownership
was approved a couple of weeks later by the NFL team owners, and Khan took
over full ownership on January 4, 2012. He immediately began the team's search
for head coaching candidates.[49]

On February 13, 2012, the Jaguars hired [MetLife
Stadium](/wiki/MetLife_Stadium "MetLife Stadium") president and CEO [Mark
Lamping](/wiki/Mark_Lamping "Mark Lamping") as team president. Lamping also
spent 13 years as the president of the [St. Louis
Cardinals](/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals"). Lamping is the
second team president in franchise history and the first since 1997, when
David Seldin left that position.[50]

####
2012[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: 2012")]

Main article: [2012 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2012_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2012 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

On January 10, 2012, former [Atlanta Falcons](/wiki/Atlanta_Falcons "Atlanta
Falcons") offensive coordinator [Mike Mularkey](/wiki/Mike_Mularkey "Mike
Mularkey") was named head coach of the Jaguars. On January 13, it was
announced that interim head coach Mel Tucker would remain on the staff as
defensive coordinator/assistant head coach and that former Falcons
quarterbacks coach [Bob Bratkowski](/wiki/Bob_Bratkowski "Bob Bratkowski")
would become offensive coordinator.[51] On January 20, 2012, the team hired
[John Bonamego](/wiki/John_Bonamego "John Bonamego") as special teams
coordinator.

The Jaguars began the 2012 season with a new coaching staff and a new owner.
One of the main priorities of the new leadership was to improve the team's
struggling receiving corps and see improvement from quarterback Blaine Gabbert
after a disappointing rookie season. To do this, the team selected wide
receiver [Justin Blackmon](/wiki/Justin_Blackmon "Justin Blackmon") in the
first round of the [2012 NFL Draft](/wiki/2012_NFL_Draft "2012 NFL Draft") and
acquired [Laurent Robinson](/wiki/Laurent_Robinson "Laurent Robinson") in free
agency. Despite the changes, the team struggled mightily on both sides of the
ball. The team finished with a 2–14 record, the worst in franchise history.
Both general manager [Gene
Smith](/wiki/Gene_Smith_\(American_football_executive\) "Gene Smith \(American
football executive\)") and head coach [Mike Mularkey](/wiki/Mike_Mularkey
"Mike Mularkey") were fired shortly after the end of the season.[52]

#### NFL International
Series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: NFL International Series")]

Main article: [NFL International Series](/wiki/NFL_International_Series "NFL
International Series")

On August 21, 2012, the Jaguars announced they had finalized a deal to play
one regular season home game each year between 2013 and 2016 at
[London](/wiki/London "London")'s historic [Wembley
Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium") as part of the [NFL
International Series](/wiki/NFL_International_Series "NFL International
Series").[53] The first of these games was against the [San Francisco
49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers") on October 27,
2013.[54][55] This deal was later extended through 2020.[56]

###
2013–2016[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: 2013–2016")]

Main article: [2013 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2013_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2013 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Airman%2C_Jaguars_take_American_football_to_UK%27s_capital_131027-F-WZ808-034.jpg/330px-
Airman%2C_Jaguars_take_American_football_to_UK%27s_capital_131027-F-WZ808-034.jpg)](/wiki/File:Airman,_Jaguars_take_American_football_to_UK%27s_capital_131027-F-WZ808-034.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Airman,_Jaguars_take_American_football_to_UK%27s_capital_131027-F-WZ808-034.jpg
"Enlarge")

Jaguars take the field in [London](/wiki/London "London"), [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") on October 27, 2013.

On January 8, 2013, former [Atlanta Falcons](/wiki/Atlanta_Falcons "Atlanta
Falcons") Director of Player Personnel [David
Caldwell](/wiki/David_Caldwell_\(American_football_executive\) "David Caldwell
\(American football executive\)") was hired as the second full-time General
Manager in Jaguars history.[57] He formerly served as a scout for the
[Indianapolis Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis Colts") for 10
years from 1998–2007. His first task with the team was to lead the interview
process for a new head coach. Nine days later former [Seattle
Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle Seahawks") defensive coordinator
[Gus Bradley](/wiki/Gus_Bradley "Gus Bradley") was named head coach of the
Jaguars.[58] The Jaguars struggled early on in 2013 and went into the bye week
with an 0–8 record. On November 1 [Justin Blackmon](/wiki/Justin_Blackmon
"Justin Blackmon") was suspended indefinitely after violating the NFL's Policy
and Program for Substances of Abuse.[59] Despite the loss of Blackmon the
Jaguars got their first win with Gus Bradley on November 10 with a 29–27
victory over the [Tennessee Titans](/wiki/2013_Tennessee_Titans_season "2013
Tennessee Titans season"). This was followed by a respectable showing against
the [Arizona Cardinals](/wiki/2013_Arizona_Cardinals_season "2013 Arizona
Cardinals season"), despite a 27–14 loss, and the Jaguars' second and third
victory of the season against the [Houston
Texans](/wiki/2013_Houston_Texans_season "2013 Houston Texans season") and the
[Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns"). The Jaguars
would win again the very next week against the Houston Texans 27–20 on
Thursday night, improving to 4–9. They finished the season 4–12.

####
2014–2015[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: 2014–2015")]

Main articles: [2014 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2014_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2014 Jacksonville Jaguars
season") and [2015 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2015_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2015 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Blake_Bortles_hands_off_to_Toby_Gerhart_vs._Ravens_2014.jpg/270px-
Blake_Bortles_hands_off_to_Toby_Gerhart_vs._Ravens_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Blake_Bortles_hands_off_to_Toby_Gerhart_vs._Ravens_2014.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Blake_Bortles_hands_off_to_Toby_Gerhart_vs._Ravens_2014.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Blake Bortles](/wiki/Blake_Bortles "Blake Bortles") handing off to [Toby
Gerhart](/wiki/Toby_Gerhart "Toby Gerhart") in December 2014.

After finishing the 2013 season with a 4–12 record, a two-win improvement over
the previous season, the Jaguars traded their [2011 NFL
draft](/wiki/2011_NFL_draft "2011 NFL draft") first round draft pick [Blaine
Gabbert](/wiki/Blaine_Gabbert "Blaine Gabbert") to the [San Francisco
49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers") for the 6th round pick
of the [2014 NFL draft](/wiki/2014_NFL_draft "2014 NFL draft").[60] [Maurice
Jones-Drew](/wiki/Maurice_Jones-Drew "Maurice Jones-Drew"), after 7 years with
the Jaguars, also left the team and signed a three-year contract with the
[Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders").[61]

In the first round of the [2014 NFL draft](/wiki/2014_NFL_draft "2014 NFL
draft") the Jaguars selected quarterback [Blake Bortles](/wiki/Blake_Bortles
"Blake Bortles") from [University of Central
Florida](/wiki/University_of_Central_Florida "University of Central Florida")
and then wide receiver [Marqise Lee](/wiki/Marqise_Lee "Marqise Lee") from
[University of Southern California](/wiki/University_of_Southern_California
"University of Southern California") in the second round. The new draft picks
helped put more confidence in the struggling team.[62] [Justin
Blackmon](/wiki/Justin_Blackmon "Justin Blackmon") was suspended yet again for
violating the NFL's Policy and Program for Substances of Abuse in July.[63]
Later in July, EverBank Field unveiled their two new endzone scoreboards,
which are considered to be the world's largest.[64] The Jaguars managed to end
their season with a 3–13 record.[65]

[Dante Fowler Jr.](/wiki/Dante_Fowler_Jr. "Dante Fowler Jr.") was selected by
the Jaguars as the third overall pick in the [2015 NFL
draft](/wiki/2015_NFL_draft "2015 NFL draft").[66] However, Fowler tore his
ACL at rookie minicamp on May 8 and did not return for the 2015 season.[67]
[Josh Scobee](/wiki/Josh_Scobee "Josh Scobee") was traded to the [Pittsburgh
Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") for a [2016 NFL
Draft](/wiki/2016_NFL_Draft "2016 NFL Draft") sixth round pick. [Jason
Myers](/wiki/Jason_Myers "Jason Myers") took over as the main placekicker for
the Jaguars.[68] The Jaguars finished the 2015 season with a record of 5–11,
the team's fifth straight losing season and their eighth straight non-winning
season.

JaguarsEverbank15.jpg)](/wiki/File:JaguarsEverbank15.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:JaguarsEverbank15.jpg "Enlarge")

[The Star-Spangled Banner](/wiki/The_Star-Spangled_Banner "The Star-Spangled
Banner") performed before a Jacksonville Jaguars game at [EverBank
Field](/wiki/EverBank_Field "EverBank Field") in 2015.

####
2016–2017[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: 2016–2017")]

Main article: [2016 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2016_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2016 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

With plenty of cap space to work with, Jacksonville splurged in free agency,
adding defensive tackle [Malik
Jackson](/wiki/Malik_Jackson_\(defensive_lineman\) "Malik Jackson \(defensive
lineman\)") from the [Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos")
and cornerback [Prince Amukamara](/wiki/Prince_Amukamara "Prince Amukamara")
from the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants"). With the
fifth selection, the Jaguars selected cornerback [Jalen
Ramsey](/wiki/Jalen_Ramsey "Jalen Ramsey") from [Florida State
University](/wiki/Florida_State_University "Florida State University") in the
first round and then the second round linebacker [Myles Jack](/wiki/Myles_Jack
"Myles Jack") of [UCLA](/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles
"University of California, Los Angeles") in the [2016 NFL
Draft](/wiki/2016_NFL_Draft "2016 NFL Draft").[69] Jack was considered to be a
top-10 talent, but fell to the second round due to a knee injury. On October
2, 2016, the Jacksonville Jaguars defeated the [Indianapolis
Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis Colts") 30–27 in the [NFL
International Series](/wiki/NFL_International_Series "NFL International
Series") game.[70] On December 18, 2016, Gus Bradley was fired after the
Jaguars' ninth loss in a row during the 2016 season. Bradley's W-L record as
head coach of the Jaguars was 14–48 in three seasons.[71]

###
2017–present[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: 2017–present")]

Main article: [2017 Jacksonville Jaguars
season](/wiki/2017_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2017 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")

On January 9, 2017 the Jaguars announced the interim head coach Doug Marrone
was to be the new head coach, the contract of General Manager David Caldwell
was to be extended and [Tom Coughlin](/wiki/Tom_Coughlin "Tom Coughlin") was
returning to Jacksonville to become Executive Vice President of Football
Operations. Both Doug Marrone and David Caldwell report to the Executive Vice
President Tom Coughlin.[72]

In the first round of the [2017 NFL Draft](/wiki/2017_NFL_Draft "2017 NFL
Draft") the Jaguars selected running back [Leonard
Fournette](/wiki/Leonard_Fournette "Leonard Fournette") of
[LSU](/wiki/LSU_Tigers_football "LSU Tigers football").[73] At the annual [NFL
International Series](/wiki/NFL_International_Series "NFL International
Series") in [London](/wiki/London "London") on September 24, 2017 Jaguars
players locked arms and kneeled during the national anthem in response to
President [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s remarks on NFL
players who kneel. Shahid Khan also participated with the Jaguars in locking
arms during the anthem and the Baltimore Ravens kneeled on the opposite side
of the field. The Jaguars went on to defeat the Ravens in a 44-7 win.[74] Four
weeks later on October 17, President of the Jaguars [Mark
Lamping](/wiki/Mark_Lamping "Mark Lamping") sent a letter of apology to the
director of military affairs and veterans in Jacksonville that says the
Jaguars were ”remiss in not fully comprehending the effect of the national
anthem demonstration on foreign soil has had on the men and women who have or
continue to serve our country.”[75]

After their week 15 win over the [Houston Texans](/wiki/Houston_Texans
"Houston Texans"), the Jaguars clinched their first playoff trip since
[2007](/wiki/2007_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2007 Jacksonville Jaguars
season"); they finished the season 10-6, a seven-game turnaround from the
previous year. The Jaguars defeated the [Buffalo Bills](/wiki/Buffalo_Bills
"Buffalo Bills") 10-3 in Jacksonville, marking the first playoff win in ten
years.[76] In the Divisional Round, on January 14, 2018, the Jaguars defeated
the [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers")
45-42 in Pittsburgh[77] to advance to their 3rd [AFC Championship
Game](/wiki/AFC_Championship_Game "AFC Championship Game"), and their first
since [1999](/wiki/1999_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "1999 Jacksonville Jaguars
season"). However, they narrowly fell to the New England Patriots 24-20.[78]
For the season, the defense earned the nickname "Sacksonville" because of its
dominance.

## Team colors, logos and
mascot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Team colors, logos and mascot")]

###
Logos[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Logos")]

The day after the NFL awarded the expansion team to Jacksonville, a triumphant
Wayne Weaver held up the Jaguars' proposed silver helmet and teal jersey at
the NFL owners' meeting in Chicago. The team's colors were to be teal, gold,
and silver with black accents. However, this jersey and helmet design, with a
gold leaping jaguar, created controversy. [Ford Motor
Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford Motor Company"), then-parent of the
automaker [Jaguar](/wiki/Jaguar_\(car\) "Jaguar \(car\)"), believed that the
Jaguars' logo bore too much resemblance to the automaker's logo. Though no
lawsuit was brought to trial, lawyers from the team and the automaker
negotiated an ultimately amicable agreement whereby Jaguar would be named the
official car of the Jaguars, and the Jaguars would redesign their uniforms.

The new logo was a snarling jaguar head with a teal tongue, which Weaver said
was his wife's touch. He also claimed that the teal tongue came from "feeding
Panthers to our Jaguars" — an obvious jab at [their expansion
brethren](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers"). During the Jaguars'
first ever preseason game teal-colored candies were handed out to all the fans
who attended, turning their tongues a teal color just like on the logo.
Additionally, raspberry lollipops were handed out by the "Candy Man" in
section 142 to also turn the home fans' tongues teal.

In 2009, Weaver announced that he wanted to 'clean up' the team's image. This
meant the elimination of the full-body crawling Jaguar logo, the clawing
Jaguar, and the two previous wordmarks which bent the text around these logos.

In February 2013, Jaguars owner [Shahid Khan](/wiki/Shahid_Khan "Shahid
Khan"), who had acquired the team in late 2011, introduced a new brand
identity for the team that included a new logo, wordmark, and secondary logo.
The new [Jaguar](/wiki/Jaguar "Jaguar") head logo was intended to be "fiercer"
and more realistic.[79] The secondary logo incorporated the new Jaguar head
logo along with the first official usage of the team's popular nickname
"Jags". The two images were incased in a shield-style shape, designed to be a
tribute to Jacksonville's military community.[2]

Beginning in 2013, the Jaguars began to feature gold more prominently than in
the past. In fact, from 2009–12 gold had only been used in the team logo and
as a minor accent color.

###
Uniforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Uniforms")]

For most of their history, the Jaguars have done what many other NFL teams
located in [subtropical climates](/wiki/Subtropical_climate "Subtropical
climate") traditionally practice: wear their white jerseys at home during the
first half of the season — forcing opponents to wear their dark ones under the
sweltering autumns in Jacksonville. The only exceptions were in 2004 and
2008–10, when the Jaguars chose to wear teal for all home games. In the
preseason, the Jaguars typically wear teal at home since these games are
played at night when there is very little advantage with the heat.

####
1995–2001[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: 1995–2001")]

Following the logo change, the redesigned uniforms featured an all-black
helmet, white pants with teal, black, and gold stripes, and numbers with gold
inner trim and black outer trim. The home jersey was teal with white numbers
and the away jersey was white with teal numbers. Both jerseys had a black
collar and no sleeve stripes.

A prowling jaguar on each sleeve replaced the leaping jaguar going across both
shoulders in the original design. The Jaguars in 1995 were the first NFL team
to have 2-tone borders on their numbers and lettering, and the first NFL team
to show a complex logo (the crawling Jaguar) on the sleeve.

Minor modifications were introduced to the Jaguars uniform during this time,
most notably the font of the jersey numbers, replacing the original block
numbers with a unique font. Two stripes were also added to the end of the
sleeves below the prowling jaguar.

####
2002–2008[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: 2002–2008")]

During this period, the Jaguars made minor changes to their uniform, each time
adding more black to the look.

The team introduced a black alternate jersey in 2002. During that same year,
the team also introduced alternate black pants, worn with either the white or
the teal jersey. After the black pants were introduced, the white pants would
only be seen for the first few games of the year, presumably due to the heat.
The black pants originally included two teal stripes down each side. The fan
reaction to the extra black in the alternate jersey and alternate pants was
positive, so in 2004 the Jaguars went through a formal uniform change, which
teams are only allowed to do once every five years. These changes were mostly
to the away look. Before 2004, the white away jerseys had teal numbers with
black and gold trim, but after, the white jerseys had black numbers with teal
and gold trim. The black pants were also changed. The teal stripes were
replaced with the Jaguar logo on each hip. Teal almost disappeared from the
away uniform.

The stripes on the white pants were altered in 2008 so that the center,
thickest stripe was black, and its accents were teal. In the 2008 year, the
gold in the uniforms noticeably shifted from a bright yellow metallic
appearance to more beige.

####
2009–2011[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: 2009–2011")]

The Jaguars unveiled new uniforms for the [2009
season](/wiki/2009_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2009 Jacksonville Jaguars
season").[15][80] Team owner [Wayne Weaver](/wiki/Wayne_Weaver "Wayne Weaver")
reportedly wanted to "clean up" the look, feeling that the team had too many
uniform styles.[15] The new uniforms were introduced in a press conference on
April 22.[81]

At this press conference, Weaver elaborated that different people had taken
different liberties with the Jaguars' image over the years, singling out the
'All Black' look which the team wore for every prime-time home game from 2003
to 2007 as a point of regret. He also said that the team would wear their teal
jerseys at home even on hot days, saying that the practice of choosing to wear
white on hot days had also diluted the team's image. The new uniform reflected
a simpler look overall. The collar and sleeve ends are the same color as the
rest of the jersey. The crawling jaguar was removed. The numbers on the
jerseys were changed to a simpler, block font with a thicker, single color
border. After all of these subtractions, two features were added. The first
was a "JAGUARS" wordmark underneath the NFL insignia on the chest. The second
was two thin 'stripes' of off-color fabric which were added to each midseam of
the jersey, curling up to the neckline on the front and below the number on
the back. The stripe on the home jersey is a white line next to a black line,
matching the color of the numbers, and the stripe on the away jersey is a
black line next to a teal line, again matching the numbers. The pants have
similar stripes, both for the home and away uniform. The away uniforms were
still black pants and numbers on a white jersey, but they now used teal as the
only accent color as opposed to using gold in previous years. The Jaguars'
identity, in terms of colors, beginning in 2009 is exclusively teal and black,
with gold only being used in the logo. The final change made to the Jaguars'
uniforms in 2009 was to the helmet. The new helmet and facemask were black
just like the old ones, but when light hit the new ones a certain way, both
the helmet and face mask sparkled with a shiny teal appearance. These were the
first helmets in professional football which changed color with different
angles of light. The logo and number decals also incorporated this effect.[82]

####
2012[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: 2012")]

Prior to the [2012 season](/wiki/2012_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2012
Jacksonville Jaguars season"), new Jaguars owner Shahid Khan announced that
the team would once again use a black jersey, something they had not done
since 2008. In September of that year, the team announced that it would use
the black jersey and black pants as their primary home uniform. The teal
jersey was resurrected as an alternate.[83]

####
2013–present[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: 2013–present")]

On April 23, 2013, the Jaguars unveiled new uniforms designed by
[Nike](/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc."). The primary home jersey is black with
white numerals outlined in teal and gold. The road jersey is white with teal
numerals outlined in black and gold, marking the first time since 2003 that
the team has used teal numbers on their road jersey. The alternate jersey is
teal with black numerals outlined in white and gold. The team had never before
used black numbers on their teal jersey. All three jerseys feature a
contrasting stripe that bends around the neck, and semi-glossy patches on the
shoulders meant to resemble claw marks. The team added their new shield logo
onto a patch just above the player's heart, meant to pay tribute to
Jacksonville's military heritage.[84]

The helmet, first of its kind in the NFL, features a glossy gold finish in the
back that fades to matte black in the front, via a [color
gradient](/wiki/Color_gradient "Color gradient").[85]

The new uniform set includes black and white pants with the Jaguars logo on
the hip and a tri-color pattern down the player's leg.

In November 2015, as one of eight teams participating in Nike's "Color Rush"
initiative for four games of _Thursday Night Football_ during the 2015 season,
Jacksonville introduced an all-gold second alternative uniform. The set
features a gold jersey with black sleeves and black trim, as well as all gold
pants. The white front and back numbers are lined in the teal accent color and
bordered by black. The TV numbers on the shoulders are white with black
bordering. The set also features gold undershirts and socks.[86]

###
Mascot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Mascot")]

Main article: [Jaxson de Ville](/wiki/Jaxson_de_Ville "Jaxson de Ville")

See also: [Curtis Dvorak](/wiki/Curtis_Dvorak "Curtis Dvorak")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Phil_Stacey_American_Idol_finalist.jpg/220px-
Phil_Stacey_American_Idol_finalist.jpg)](/wiki/File:Phil_Stacey_American_Idol_finalist.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Phil_Stacey_American_Idol_finalist.jpg "Enlarge")

Jaxson de Ville with _[American Idol](/wiki/American_Idol "American Idol")_
[season 6](/wiki/American_Idol_\(season_6\) "American Idol \(season 6\)")
finalist [Phil Stacey](/wiki/Phil_Stacey "Phil Stacey").

Since his introduction in 1996, Jaxson de Ville has served as the Jaguars'
mascot. Jaxson entertains the crowd before and during games with his antics.
The mascot has established a reputation for making dramatic entrances
including bungee jumping off the stadium lights, sliding down a rope from the
scoreboard and parachuting into the stadium.

Jaxson's antics got him into trouble in 1998 and stemmed the changing of the
NFL's mascot rules, and also caused him to calm down.[87] However, Jaxson was
still seen, by some, as a mascot that gets in the way during the game. After
the October 22, 2007 game against Indianapolis, Colts President Bill Polian
complained to the NFL, and Jaxson was reprimanded again.[88][89]

Jaxson's first appearance was on August 18, 1996[90] and was played by [Curtis
Dvorak](/wiki/Curtis_Dvorak "Curtis Dvorak") from his inception until his
retirement in June 2015.[91]

### Jacksonville
Roar[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Jacksonville Roar")]

Main article: [Jacksonville Roar](/wiki/Jacksonville_Roar "Jacksonville Roar")

The Jacksonville Roar is the professional [cheerleading](/wiki/Cheerleading
"Cheerleading") squad of the Jaguars. The group was established in 1995, the
team's inaugural year, and regularly performs choreographed routines during
the team's home contests.[92]

In addition to performing at games and pep rallies, members function as
[goodwill](/wiki/Good_faith "Good faith") [ambassadors](/wiki/Ambassador
"Ambassador") of the team, participating in corporate, community, and
charitable events in the [Jacksonville metropolitan
area](/wiki/Jacksonville_metropolitan_area "Jacksonville metropolitan
area")[93] where they sign autographs and pose for pictures. They also join
NFL tours to entertain American servicemen and women around the world.[93][94]

##
Stadium[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Stadium")]

Main article: [TIAA Bank Field](/wiki/TIAA_Bank_Field "TIAA Bank Field")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/EverBankField2014.jpg/499px-
EverBankField2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:EverBankField2014.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/EverBankFIeld2014.jpg/259px-
EverBankFIeld2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:EverBankFIeld2014.jpg)

[TIAA Bank Field](/wiki/TIAA_Bank_Field "TIAA Bank Field"), home of the
Jacksonville Jaguars and the world's largest scoreboards.

TIAA Bank Field (formerly known as Jacksonville Municipal Stadium, Alltel
Stadium, and EverBank Field) is located on the north bank of the [St. Johns
River](/wiki/St._Johns_River "St. Johns River"), and has been the home of the
Jaguars since the team's first season in 1995. The stadium has a capacity of
69,132, with additional seating added during [Florida–Georgia
Game](/wiki/Florida_vs._Georgia_Football_Classic "Florida vs. Georgia Football
Classic") and the [Gator Bowl](/wiki/Gator_Bowl "Gator Bowl").[95]

The stadium served as the site of [Super Bowl XXXIX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXIX
"Super Bowl XXXIX") in addition to four Jaguar playoff games including the
[1999 AFC Championship
Game](/wiki/NFL_playoffs,_1999-2000#AFC:_Tennessee_Titans_33,_Jacksonville_Jaguars_14
"NFL playoffs, 1999-2000"). It also hosted the [ACC Championship
Game](/wiki/ACC_Championship_Game "ACC Championship Game") from 2005–07 and
the River City Showdown in 2007 and 2008.

From 1995–97 and again from 2006–09, the stadium was named Jacksonville
Municipal Stadium. From 1997–2006, the stadium was referred to as Alltel
Stadium.[96] The naming rights were purchased by [EverBank](/wiki/EverBank
"EverBank") prior to the 2010 season.[97] Prior to the [2018
season](/wiki/2018_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2018 Jacksonville Jaguars
season") the Jaguars announced the stadium would be renamed TIAA Bank
Field.[98]

The stadium got a substantial upgrade in 2014 with the addition of new
scoreboards, pools, cabana seating and premium seating that includes 180
field-level seats. The scoreboards are 60 feet high and 362 feet long. The new
scoreboards at EverBank Field are now the world's largest video boards. Two 25
feet by 12 feet pools were installed in the north and south end zones along
with the cabana seating. The stadium upgrades were $63 million that owner
[Shahid Khan](/wiki/Shahid_Khan "Shahid Khan") helped finance $20 million of
the total cost.[99]

##
Rivals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Rivals")]

The Jacksonville Jaguars have three primary rivals: their divisional rivals
([Tennessee Titans](/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans"), [Indianapolis
Colts](/wiki/Indianapolis_Colts "Indianapolis Colts"), and [Houston
Texans](/wiki/Houston_Texans "Houston Texans")).[100] They have geographic
rivalries with the [Miami Dolphins](/wiki/Miami_Dolphins "Miami Dolphins") and
[Tampa Bay Buccaneers](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers "Tampa Bay Buccaneers"). The
Jaguars also have a rivalry with their 1995 expansion brethren, the Carolina
Panthers. The Jaguars also have rivalries with other teams that arose from the
AFC Central days, most notably with the [Pittsburgh
Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers").[101]

### Retired
numbers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=38
"Edit section: Retired numbers")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Prideofthejaguars15.jpg/250px-
Prideofthejaguars15.jpg)](/wiki/File:Prideofthejaguars15.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Prideofthejaguars15.jpg "Enlarge")

Pride of the Jaguars display in EverBank Field.

Although not officially retired, the number 71 worn by offensive tackle [Tony
Boselli](/wiki/Tony_Boselli "Tony Boselli"), the Jaguars' first-ever draft
pick, has not been worn since his retirement in 2002.[102] According to team
officials, while the number is not in circulation, the number (along with Fred
Taylor's number 28) is officially available for use if the circumstances
warrant it.[103]

### Pride of the
Jaguars[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=39
"Edit section: Pride of the Jaguars")]

A contest was held in July 2006 to name the club's ring of honor and "Pride of
the Jaguars" was chosen with 36% of the vote.[104] It was unveiled during the
2006 season during a game against the New York Jets on October 8. Former
offensive tackle [Tony Boselli](/wiki/Tony_Boselli "Tony Boselli") was the
first player inducted.

On January 1, 2012, team owner [Wayne Weaver](/wiki/Wayne_Weaver "Wayne
Weaver") and his wife Delores were added to the Pride of the Jaguars in their
final game before the sale of the team to [Shahid Khan](/wiki/Shahid_Khan
"Shahid Khan"). On June 7, 2012 the Jaguars announced [Fred
Taylor](/wiki/Fred_Taylor_\(American_football\) "Fred Taylor \(American
football\)") would be the next inductee into the Pride of the Jaguars.[105] He
was officially inducted on September 30, 2012. Longtime Jaguars quarterback
Mark Brunell was also inducted into the "Pride of the Jaguars" on December 15,
2013.[106]

## Work in the
community[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=47
"Edit section: Work in the community")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/JagsFound.gif/100px-
JagsFound.gif)](/wiki/File:JagsFound.gif)

[](/wiki/File:JagsFound.gif "Enlarge")

Jacksonville Jaguars Foundation

The **Jacksonville Jaguars Foundation** was established in 1994, when the
franchise deal was first announced.[109] Since then, the Foundation has given
over $20 million to area efforts in community improvement.[110] The Foundation
focuses on many initiatives, such as [Honor
Rows](/w/index.php?title=Honor_Rows&action=edit&redlink=1 "Honor Rows \(page
does not exist\)"), anti-tobacco programs, NFL Play 60, and support for
veterans.[111] The Foundation grants over $1 million annually to organizations
that assist "economically and socially disadvantaged youth and families".[112]

The Jaguars' first head coach, [Tom Coughlin](/wiki/Tom_Coughlin "Tom
Coughlin"), established the [Tom Coughlin Jay Fund
Foundation](/wiki/Tom_Coughlin_Jay_Fund_Foundation "Tom Coughlin Jay Fund
Foundation") in 1996 to help young cancer victims and their families with
emotional and financial assistance. The charity remained in Jacksonville after
Coughlin left to coach the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York
Giants").[113]

###
Radio[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jacksonville_Jaguars&action=edit&section=49
"Edit section: Radio")]

From their inaugural 1995 season until 2013, the Jaguars' flagship radio
station was [WOKV](/wiki/WOKV "WOKV"), which simulcasts on both AM 690 and on
104.5 FM.

Starting with the 2014 season, the team will be moving the broadcast to
[WJXL](/wiki/WJXL "WJXL") (1010 AM and 92.5 FM) and simulcast on 99.9 Gator
Country[114]

[Frank Frangie](/wiki/Frank_Frangie "Frank Frangie") is the [play-by-
play](/wiki/Play-by-play "Play-by-play") announcer with former Jaguars players
[Tony Boselli](/wiki/Tony_Boselli "Tony Boselli") and [Jeff
Lageman](/wiki/Jeff_Lageman "Jeff Lageman") providing color analysis.
